posts.cooked:
Currently we use trapezoidal motion profiling to bring our elevator to given setpoints. Although this method is very accurate, it isnâ€™t as fast as we would like it to be. When watching 4414, 1678, 5940, 973, or any of the top teamsâ€™ elevator control, theyâ€™re able to maintain very smooth yet extremely fast motion. If they are also using trapezoidal motion, how are we supposed to make our control faster as well? Is this simply a mechanical difference, or is there something conceptually Iâ€™m missing about trapezoidal motion profiling in general (the only ways I can find to up speed are through adjusting PID and the trapezoidal motion profiling constraints, though these only result in slightly faster motion, and nowhere near the level of the teams listed above). Iâ€™m quite certain they donâ€™t just use PID alone since that would not be as reliable as trapezoidal profiling, but Iâ€™m unsure as to how theyâ€™re able to maintain such smooth and fast control, and Iâ€™m curious to see whether there is a software fix to our current slowness in this area.

Our current code for this, if itâ€™s of any interest:

link_counts.title: ChargedUp2023/ElevatorToSetpointWithFeedForward.java at Development Â· frc-7419/ChargedUp2023 Â· GitHub

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Your speed is really pretty independent of your control scheme (mostly).  How much weight are you lifting, how far, how fast do you want it, and how many motors are you using?

posts.name: Collin
posts.cooked: After looking at your code, I would highly recommend looking into MotionMagic on the TalonFX as it provides very good tools for tuning their trapezoidal profile, and is something many top teams use due to its high accuracy. It will allow you to also define the max velocity and acceleration which will help you adjust for the speed you are looking for.

posts.name: Greg Sesny retired  5804
posts.cooked:
We also use motion magic as it is very easy and user friendly.  You can only move your elevator as fast as your hardware allows.  Motion Magic allows you control your velocity and acceleration but you have to make sure your hardware is capable of reaching those speeds.  Here is a great tutorial.

Motion Magic Tutorial from YouTube

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Do you have any counter-springs?  If you can get your arm so that it is just barely or almost lifted by the springs, all your motors have to do is accelerate the load, which will greatly improve your overall speed.
What would be the advantage of using Motion Magic over our current implementation of trapezoidal motion profiling if they utilize the same trapezoidal control?

posts.name: Jared Russell
posts.cooked: Motion magic runs onboard the Falcon at 1000Hz and isnâ€™t subject to the same degree of timing jitter as RoboRIO user code.
What exactly do you mean by timing jitter?

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
How do you get started with MotionMagic? Itâ€™s something I want to try as well. We had a decent PID working but we disabled it after I put an I value that was too big, which caused everything to break, physically

Would I start with a PID then change it to Motion Magic?

Chadfrom7226:

Would

You can find the docs to start off with here:

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

link_counts.title: Motor Controller Closed Loop â€” Phoenix documentation

posts.cooked: Start with low cruise velocity and max accel values + tune P and D like you usually would and ramp up velocity and accel. You usually never need the I term but if you really do, start super small

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked:
At a very high level, jitter is how much error there is in a periodic signal. If a control loop runs at exactly 1000Hz and exactly every 1ms it samples and updates its output, it would have 0 jitter. The Rio running at 50Hz can have a little bit of error and might loop at 19ms or 21ms (or more if your code is overrunning every once in a while). This jitter (if not taken into account) can cause odd things to happen in a control loop.

Edit: Jitter - Wikipedia

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
For reference, here is our elevator code that uses Motion Magic.

Pay no attention to the analog potentiometer, it ended up not being reliable so itâ€™s not used. Also of note, the limit switches are REV magnetic sensors so theyâ€™re connected to the roboRIO. If you can connect the limit switches to the Falcons, you can avoid some complexity.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Aqtion:

Is this simply a mechanical difference, or is there something conceptually Iâ€™m missing about trapezoidal motion profiling in general

Did you try running the elevator in open-loop at a high duty cycle, maybe 80%, and see how fast it is. (If you do this, donâ€™t forget to add some ramping so you donâ€™t break anything.) You first have to determine how fast it can physically move. You canâ€™t code around the gear ratio.

Through running the elevator manually and with motion profiling, it can definitely move faster than its top speed when using motion profiling. I know this is a given though due to the need for acceleration and deceleration resulting in a lower max speed. Iâ€™ll switch our approach to Motion Magic and see if it yields better results.
